historySlides.text: Professional golf surges internationally, as record numbers of international players compete regularly on the PGA TOUR, claiming major championships and money titles. Germany’s Bernhard Langer, Spain’s Seve Ballesteros, England’s Nick Faldo and Australia’s Greg Norman climb to the top of the Official World Golf Ranking designed to facilitate play across continents.
historySlides.title: Pro Golf Goes Global

historySlides.text: Following the trailblazing paths of Australia’s Jan Stephenson and Japan’s Chako Higuchi, the first Asian-born player to win a major championship, a cadre of international stars join the LPGA Tour, expanding the footprint of women’s professional golf. The Peter Jackson (later du Maurier) Classic earns major status on the LPGA Tour.
historySlides.title: The LPGA Grows its Reach

historySlides.text: International rivalries play out across premier team competitions. Interest in the Ryder Cup surges after 1985, when the European team wins for the first time in 28 years. Heroes emerge and legends are made at the Belfry, Muirfield Village, Kiawah Island, Valderamma, Oak Hill and Brookline as the teams trade victories.
historySlides.title: The Ryder Cup Rivalry is Reborn

historySlides.text: Surging interest in team competitions reaches the women’s game with the establishment of the Solheim Cup in 1990. The United States rolls to victory, 11 1/2 points to 4 1/2 points, in the inaugural competition at Lake Nona Golf and Country Club in Florida.
historySlides.title: The Solheim Cup Creates New Teammates and New Rivalries

historySlides.text: The format of the Ryder Cup excludes many international stars from the competition. The Presidents Cup is established in 1994 to give players from Asia, Africa, Canada and the Pacific Rim a shot at glory.
historySlides.title: International Competition Expands its Horizons

profiles.bioText:
Sir Nick Faldo won 41 professional tournaments worldwide, including six major championships, the most by any European player since World War I. Faldo demonstrated the precision and consistency for which he came to be known during the final round of the 1987 Open Championship at Muirfield, where he defeated Paul Azinger and Rodger Davis to win by one stroke to claim his first major.

Faldo also excelled at team events. He was named to a record 11 European Ryder Cup teams, played in 46 matches (also the most by any European player) and posted a record of 23-19-4. After retiring from competitive golf, Faldo became the lead golf analyst for CBS Sports and covered the Open Championship for BBC Sport.
profiles.quote: Listen to your heart and to your gut. How often have you left the house knowing you’ve forgotten something, and it turns out you have? Intuition is very powerful, and certainly it’s true in golf.

profiles.bioText:
Sandy Lyle, a native of England who came to represent Scotland as a professional, earned his stripes of one of Britain’s top golfers of the 1980s. He collected 18 victories on the European Tour and 6 on the PGA TOUR, including two major championships.

Lyle won three times in his debut year of 1979, earning him Sir Henry Cotton Rookie of the Year honors. In capturing the Open Championship in 1985, Lyle became the first British player to raise the Claret Jug since Tony Jacklin in 1969. Three years later at the Masters, Lyle recovered from a poor tee shot on the 18th hole to make a 10-foot birdie putt to become the first British golfer to win a Green Jacket.
profiles.quote: I never felt I was going to be anything but a golfer.

profiles.bioText:
Bernhard Langer, with more than 120 professional wins, took his place as one of the world's leading golfers in the 1980s and 1990s, posting victories on all six continents where golf is played. Among his most iconic victories were the 1985 Masters, when he became the second European to win at Augusta National, and a second Green Jacket in 1993. In 2007, Langer graduated to PGA TOUR Champions, going on to capture 11 major championships, achieving the career Senior Grand Slam and winning more than 40 times.

Langer played on 11 European Ryder Cup teams from 1981 to 2002. He captained the 2004 team to victory over the USA by the largest margin to date, 18½ to 9½.
profiles.quote: When you're going through a low time you just persevere, but you don't give up. You find a way to get out there.

profiles.bioText:
Graham won 37 tournaments worldwide, becoming the fourth golfer to win on six continents. His first major championship title came in the 1979 PGA Championship, when he sank a birdie putt on the third playoff hole to defeat Ben Crenshaw. Graham left his most lasting mark on golf history at the 1981 U.S. Open, carding a 67 to make up a three-shot deficit and win by three strokes. 

Graham represented Australia in three Alfred Dunhill Cups, winning the inaugural event in 1985, and on two World Cup teams, where he won in 1970 with Bruce Delvin. In 1994, he served as the captain for the International Team in the inaugural Presidents Cup at the Robert Trent Jones Golf Club.
profiles.quote: I’d like to be remembered for where I came from, to where I got to.

profiles.bioText:
Described by Greg Norman as the "Arnold Palmer of Japanese Golf," Isao Aoki helped popularize golf in Japan while becoming one of the nation's most successful golfers. After turning professional in 1964, Aoki captured more than 70 wins on six international tours. In 1983, he became the first Japanese player to win on the PGA TOUR, when he holed out from 128 yards with a wedge on the final hole of the Hawaiian Open.

One the game’s premier putters, Aoki is perhaps best remembered for finishing second at the 1980 U.S. Open at Baltusrol Golf Club. Paired with Jack Nicklaus all four days, Aoki played his best golf against the eventual winner, sharing the lead going into the final round.
profiles.quote: That was my dream – to see the world.

profiles.bioText:
Superstar Nancy Lopez burst onto the scene in 1978, winning nine tournaments, including five consecutive victories, and becoming the first and only player to claim Rookie of the Year, Player of the Year and Vare Trophy honors in the same season. She recorded nine victories in 1979. Lopez won at least two events every year from 1980 to 1985, amassed 48 career titles, and earned her place as one of the most popular players in LPGA history.

In 1990, Lopez played in the inaugural Solheim Cup, posting a 2-1-0 record, and captained the 2005 USA team to victory to regain the cup, 15½ to 12½. After retiring from professional golf, she began a clothing line and a golf course design company.
profiles.quote: Do your best, one shot at a time, and then move on. Remember that golf is just a game.

profiles.bioText:
Following a stellar junior career in which she secured three consecutive U.S. Girls’ Junior titles, Hollis Stacy won 18 times on the LPGA Tour, including four major championships. From 1977 to 1983, she recorded 82 top-ten finishes on the LPGA Tour. A noted clutch performer, she earned one-third of her LPGA titles in playoffs. She regards her victory in the 1984 U.S. Open as her most significant win, as she overcame a seven-stroke deficit to Amy Alcott and Rosie Jones with 13 holes left to play. 

Stacy is the fourth-oldest of ten children, many of whom played golf competitively. In 1985, the Stacy family received a well-deserved Family of the Year honor from the Metropolitan Golf Writers Association.
profiles.quote: I am the middle child among 10 children and I had so much psychological warfare — I wasn't going to lose.

directus_files_id.title: Player Capstone Bio1 the Global Game Donna Caponi
Player Capstone Bio2 the Global Game Donna Caponi

profiles.bioText:
After turning professional in 1965, Donna Caponi went on to record 24 LPGA victories, including four major championships. Her first win came at the 1969 U.S. Open, where she rallied from a five-shot deficit in the final round. In 1970, she became just the second woman to successfully defend her Women’s Open title. Caponi's best years came in 1980 and 1981, when she capped off her career with five victories in each year. 

After retiring from competitive golf in 1988, Caponi turned to television broadcasting and served as an analyst for CBS Sports and the Golf Channel. In 2005, Nancy Lopez named her assistant captain to the USA Solheim Cup team, which went on to defeat Europe 15½ to 12½.
profiles.quote: Golf is a fun thing with me. I wouldn't have stayed with it six years for all the money in the world if I didn't enjoy the game.

profiles.bioText:
Wither her victory at the 1977 LPGA Championship, Hisako “Chako” Higuchi became the first Japanese player, woman or man, to win a major championship. She entered the final round tied for the lead and played her way to a three-stroke victory over Sandra Post and fellow Hall of Fame members Pat Bradley and Judy Rankin. 

A founding member of the LPGA Tour of Japan in 1968, Higuchi dominated the JLPGA from the late 1960s to the 1980s. She won 69 tournaments on the JLPGA tour, 18 of which were JLPGA major championships, and earned two victories on the LPGA Tour. Four years after playing her last competitive tournament in 1990, Higuchi was named the commissioner of the JLPGA.
profiles.quote: Love and passion for golf in my life is as precious as my family and friends. Love and passion for golf motivates me to work harder – it was all for this wonderful game of golf.

profiles.bioText:
As an outstanding amateur in Australia, Jan Stephenson won six consecutive State Schoolgirl championship titles. She  turned professional in 1973 and won the Wills Australian Ladies Open that year. Stephenson joined the LPGA Tour in1974, posting six top-tens and winning Rookie of the Year honors. 

LPGA Commissioner Ray Volpe asked Stephenson to be the new "face" and "Glamour Girl" of the tour after her first win at the 1976 Sarah Coventry Naples Classic. Notably, she would go on to win 16 times on the LPGA Tour and 41 times worldwide. During her win at the U.S. Women's Open, Stephenson battled sweltering heat and used a set of borrowed clubs to win by one stroke over JoAnne Carner and Patty Sheehan.
profiles.quote: Having a good time is winning the tournament.

directus_files_id.title: Player Capstone Bio1 the Global Game Amy Alcott

profiles.bioText:
As a junior golfer, Amy Alcott created holes in her family’s backyard to help refine her game. Her hard work paid off in 1973, as she won the U.S. Girls’ Junior Championship. She turned professional two years later, winning the 1975 Orange Blossom Classic during her rookie year. 

Alcott would go on to collect 28 LPGA Tour titles, including five major championships, leaving her lasting legacy at the Nabisco Dinah Shore Classic. After her win in 1988, Alcott jumped into Poppie’s Pond, located off the 18th green at the Mission Hills Country Club. In 1991 along with tournament host Dinah Shore, Alcott jumped in again, and the spontaneous leap began by Alcott became a tradition for all champions after 1995.
profiles.quote: You have to be a perfectionist. You have to hate playing badly more than you love playing well. You have to hate losing more than you love winning.

profiles.bioText:
Frances Rose "Dinah" Shore rose to popularity as a singer and radio host during the 1940s and 1950s. With a string of eighty charted hits from 1940 to 1957, she became the first singer of her era to achieve huge solo success. She appeared in a handful of feature films that launched her four-decade career in American television.

In 1972, Colgate's chairman David Foster approached Shore to host a new tournament for the LPGA Tour. She agreed and became an engaged leader of the Colgate Dinah Shore Championship. Even with numerous sponsorship changes over the years, Shore's legacy endures at Mission Hills Country Club in Rancho Mirage, California, where a statue of Dinah greets players as they come off the 18th green.
profiles.quote: Golf is a tempestuous, lousy lover; it’s totally unpredictable, a constant surprise.

directus_files_id.description: Judy Bell, ca. 1960
directus_files_id.title: Player Capstone Bio1 the Global Game Judy Bell

profiles.bioText:
Judy Bell found success early, winning the girls’ division of the 1947 Broadmoor Ladies Invitation at 11 years old. At age 15, she captured her first of three Kansas State Women’s Amateur titles. Bell played on the victorious 1960 and 1962 Curtis Cup teams and captained the USA team to victory over Great Britain & Ireland in 1986 and 1988.

Bell joined the USGA as a volunteer for the 1961 Junior Championship Committee. In the 1970s, she became a Rules Official, and in 1987 was named the first female member of USGA Executive Committee. In 1996, she became the first woman appointed USGA President. Bell established the USGA’s "For the Good of the Game" grants program to bring golf into the lives of non-traditional players.
profiles.quote: We must all remember that strength without character is weakness.

directus_files_id.description: Bill Campbell during the 1971 Waller Cup played on the Old Course at St. Andrews
directus_files_id.title: Player Capstone Bio1 the Global Game William Campbell

profiles.bioText:
West Virginia native and Princeton University graduate William C. "Bill" Campbell captured the 1964 U.S. Amateur Championship and two U.S. Senior Amateur Championships among his 32 significant titles as an amateur. Only Chick Evans (50) played in the U.S. Amateur more times than Campbell (37), and not even Evans played in 33 consecutively as Campbell did. Campbell also participated in eight U.S. Walker Cup teams from 1951-1975, posting a remarkable singles record of 7-0-1. 

Campbell served as the President for the USGA from 1982-1983. In 1987, he became the third American to be named Captain of the Royal and Ancient Golf Club of St. Andrews, making him the first man to hold both titles.
profiles.quote: I don’t know a better way to know and enjoy people than through the medium of golf. Golf is a catalyst between golfers of different locations, countries and languages. Golf becomes the common denominator of different people.

directus_files_id.description: Sir Michael Bonallack, ca. 1955
directus_files_id.title: Player Capstone Bio1 the Global Game Michael Bonallack

profiles.bioText:
A force in British amateur golf from the 1950s through the 1970s, Sir Michael Bonallack won five British Amateur Championships from 1961-1970. He competed on nine Walker Cup teams for Great Britain & Ireland between 1957 and 1973, winning as playing captain in 1971. 

Bonallack's enduring impact followed his retirement from competitive golf, when he emerged as one of the game's leading administrators, serving as president of the English Golf Union and PGA of Great Britain and Ireland, and then as chairman of the British Golf Foundation. These positions laid the groundwork for Bonallack to become the Secretary of the Royal and Ancient Golf Club of St Andrews from 1983 to 1999, and he would be named the millennium captain in 2000.
profiles.quote: If you can accept the bad bounces and be grateful for the good bounces, you can do the same in life.

directus_files_id.description: Peggy Kirk Bell and Arnold Palmer, ca. 2000
directus_files_id.title: Player Capstone Bio2 the Global Game Peggy Kirk Bell

profiles.bioText:
An outstanding amateur Peggy Kirk Bell won three consecutive Ohio Women's Amateur titles, the 1949 Women’s North and South Amateur, and the 1949 Titleholders Championship – considered a major at the time. She joined the LPGA Tour as a charter member in 1950, the same year she participated in the Curtis Cup. 

After several years on the LPGA Tour, Bell and her husband Warren purchased Pine Needles Lodge & Golf Club in Southern Pines, N.C., and turned it into one of the finest playing and practice facilities in the country.  Bell spread and taught her passion as the owner and head golf instructor, where she developed a program called a "Golfari," a week-long excursion into golf to introduce women to the game.
profiles.quote: She lived from day to day for the betterment of golf.

directus_files_id.description: Judy Rankin on the practice range, ca. 1974
directus_files_id.title: Player Capstone Bio1 the Global Game Judy Rankin

profiles.bioText:
Judy Rankin won 26 times on the LPGA Tour, earning back-to-back Player of the Year awards in 1976 and 1977, and the Vare Trophy for the lowest scoring average in 1973, 1976 and 1977. In 1976, Rankin won six times, becoming the first player to win more than $100,000 during one season. In 1977, she recorded 25 top-10 finishes. 

After retiring from competitive golf, Rankin joined ABC Sports as a commentator and beginning in 2010, took over as lead LPGA analyst for the Golf Channel. Rankin also captained victorious Solheim Cup teams in 1996 and 1998, and called her service as captain “the greatest reward after the end of a fine career.”
profiles.quote: They say if you’re lucky in life, you find work you love, that you’re good at, and that makes a difference. To have found that twice in my life has been a blessing beyond measure.

directus_files_id.description: Sandra Haynie, 1971
directus_files_id.title: Player Capstone Bio1 the Global Game Sandra Haynie

profiles.bioText:
Sandra Haynie, one of the most dominant players of the 1960s and 1970s, claimed 42 LPGA victories, including four major championships. She won 39 times between 1962 and 1975, but stepped away in 1977 due to an ulcer and circulation problems in her left hand. 

Haynie completed her comeback in 1981 by winning the Henredon Classic, and in 1982 she won back-to-back tournaments, the Rochester International and the Peter Jackson Classic to cap off her career. Her knee gave out in 1984, and in 1985 she underwent electrode treatment to deaden the sensitivity in her lower back. Haynie passed the $1 million mark in career earnings in 1988, and then left the game on her own terms at last in 1989.
profiles.quote: In your approach to golf, no one can tell you what to do. Just as in life, you are presented with options; it's up to you to decide which ones suit you best.

directus_files_id.title: Player Capstone Bio1 the Global Game Susie Maxwell Berning

profiles.bioText:
Soon after she was introduced to golf at age 15, Susie Maxwell Berning won three consecutive Oklahoma State High School Championships from 1959 to 1961. She turned professional in 1964, garnering LPGA Rookie of the Year honors. She won her first tournament one year later at the 1965 Muskogee Civitan Open. 

Berning would go on to post 11 victories, including four major championships: the 1965 Women’s Western Open and the U.S. Women’s Open in 1968, 1972, and 1973. She is one of just six women to claim three or more U.S. Women’s Open titles. She joined the instructional staff of the Nicholas-Flick Golf Academy after retiring from the tour in 1995.
profiles.quote: I've had a good life. I've made a lot of really dear friends, and I think that's one thing that golf does for you.

directus_files_id.description: Needs Caption
directus_files_id.title: Player Capstone Bio1 the Global Game Larry Nelson

profiles.bioText:
After completing a tour of duty during the Vietnam War, Larry Nelson learned to play golf by reading Ben Hogan’s "The Five Fundamentals of Golf." Within three years, he qualified for the PGA TOUR, where he won 10 times, including three major championships. Nelson posted 65-67 in the closing rounds of the 1983 U.S. Open at Oakmont, becoming the first player to shoot 10 under par for the last 36 holes of the U.S. Open.

Nelson was named to the USA Ryder Cup Team in 1979, 1981 and 1989. He went undefeated in his first two appearances, posting a 9-0-0 record. Nelson transitioned to PGA TOUR Champions after turning 50 in 1997 and went on to win 19 times.
profiles.quote: I didn't pick golf. It picked me.

directus_files_id.description: Ray Floyd plays an approach shot at the NCR Club in the final round of the 1969 PGA Championship
directus_files_id.title: Player Capstone Bio1 the Global Game Ray Floyd

profiles.bioText:
A model of consistency and a steely competitor throughout his career, Floyd won 18 PGA TOUR events, as well as four major championships, across four decades. His first and last victories on the PGA TOUR came 29 years apart. In 1986, at age 43, he became the then-oldest player to win the U.S. Open. In 1992, Floyd became the first player to win on the PGA TOUR and PGA TOUR Champions in the same year. 

Floyd was named eight USA Ryder Cup teams between 1969 and 1993. In his final appearance, he became the oldest player to play in the Ryder Cup at 51 years old, earning three points as the United States retained the Ryder Cup in a 15-to-13 victory.
profiles.quote: They call it golf because all of the other four-letter words were taken.

directus_files_id.title: Player Capstone Bio2 the Global Game Hubert Green

profiles.bioText:
With a homegrown swing that featured low hands and a quick tempo, Hubert Green honed one of the finest short games in golf history. He was also known for making big putts when they mattered most, using a distinctive split-handed grip and an old hickory-shafted blade. In 1971, he captured his first PGA Tour title at the Houston Champions International, helping him to secure Rookie-of-the-Year honors. He would go on to record 19 PGA TOUR victories, with his last win coming at the 1985 PGA Championship.

Green played on three USA Ryder Cup teams, going undefeated in singles play. He captured four tournaments from 1998 to 2002 on PGA TOUR Champions before retiring from competitive golf in 2009.
profiles.quote: Winning breeds confidence and confidence breeds winning.

directus_files_id.description: Lanny Wadkins, 1971 Virginia State Open champion
directus_files_id.title: Player Capstone Bio1 the Global Game Lanny Wadkins

profiles.bioText:
Lanny Wadkins, the winner of 21 events on the PGA TOUR, thrived in head-to-head competition. His reputation as a fierce competitor was established during his amateur career, with victories in the 1970 U.S Amateur and Western Amateur. During the 1977 PGA Championship, Wadkins won the first sudden-death playoff in the stroke-play era of major championships on the third extra hole at Pebble Beach. The highlights of his career were his Ryder Cup appearances, where he boasted a 22-11-3 record as an eight-time member of the USA Team between 1977 and 1993. 

Wadkins began his broadcast career for CBS Sports in 2000, and he joined Golf Channel and NBC as their PGA TOUR Champions lead analyst in 2011.
profiles.quote: I've always set my goals very high. I think a person's goals should be almost unattainable. Then you try harder.

directus_files_id.description: Hale Irwin lines up a putt in the final round of the 1979 U.S. Open at the Inverness Club in Toledo, Ohio
directus_files_id.title: Player Capstone Bio1 the Global Game Hale Irwin

profiles.bioText:
Three-time U.S. Open champion Hale Irwin collected more than 80 wins worldwide with 20 victories on the PGA TOUR, 45 wins on PGA TOUR Champions and 17 international titles. He also competed on five victorious USA Ryder Cup teams, posting a record of 13-5-2. 

In 1974, Irwin survived the “Massacre at Winged Foot” to earn his first U.S. Open win by two strokes. In 1990 at Medinah, he became the oldest U.S. Open champion at age 45. He sank a 45-foot birdie putt on the 72nd hole to force an 18-hole playoff with Mike Donald, then, after finishing the playoff still tied, sealed the victory with birdie putt on the first sudden-death hole in U.S. Open history.
profiles.quote: Golf brings out your assets and liabilities as a person. The longer you play, the more certain you are that a man's performance is the outward manifestation of who, in his heart, he really thinks he is.

directus_files_id.description: Tom Watson celebrates his victory on the final green at Pebble Beach, 1982 U.S. Open
directus_files_id.title: Player Capstone Bio1 the Global Game Tom Watson

profiles.bioText:
Tom Watson, the winner of eight major championships and 39 PGA TOUR events, had a penchant for dramatic moments. The first thrilling finish of his career came at the 1975 Open Championship, where he sank a 20-foot putt to force a playoff, which he won the following day. The most memorable shot Watson ever made came in the final round of the 1982 U.S. Open at Pebble Beach, where he holed out from the greenside rough on the 17th hole for birdie, en route to a two-stroke victory.

Following his success on the PGA TOUR, where he was the leading money winner five times, Watson joined PGA TOUR Champions in 1999 and added six senior major championship titles to his resume.
profiles.quote: No other game combines the wonder of nature with the discipline of sport in such carefully planned ways.

profiles.bioText:
Johnny Miller carded eight birdies and one bogey in the final round of the 1973 U.S. Open at Oakmont, becoming the first player to shoot 63 in a major championship. He came from six strokes off the lead to win by one. The following year, Miller won eight tournaments, including the first three of the year, and dethroned Jack Nicklaus as the TOUR’s leading money winner. He would go on to record 25 career professional victories, including the 1976 Open Championship.

After retiring from professional golf, Miller became the lead golf analyst for NBC Sports from 1990 to 2019. In 1994, although semi-retired from competitive play, he won the AT&T Pebble Beach National Pro-Am.
profiles.quote: It’s not so much what you accomplish in life that really matters, but what you overcome that proves who you are, what you are, and whether you are a champion.

profiles.bioText:
José María Olazábal, the first golfer to win the R&A’s Boys Amateur and the British Boys, Youths, and Amateur titles, won more than 20 times on the European Tour and six times on the PGA TOUR, including 1994 and 1999 Masters. 

Olazábal made his Ryder Cup debut for the European team at age 21 and went on to play in seven Ryder Cup matched from 1987 to 2006. Paired Seve Ballesteros for 15 matches, the "Spanish Armada" compiled a record of 11-2-2. In 2012, Olazábal captained Europe to the greatest comeback in Ryder Cup history, leading his squad to a 14½ to 13½ victory after starting the singles matches with a 10-6 deficit to the USA team.
profiles.quote: Golf has been a great teacher in life for me. It has taught me to be disciplined, that there are no short cuts in life, you have to work really hard to achieve your goals...And most important of all, to respect others.

profiles.bioText:
In a career that spanned three decades, Seve Ballesteros won a record 50 events on the European Tour, collected nine wins on the PGA TOUR and captured five major championships. 
With his victory in the 1979 Open Championship at Royal Lytham and St. Annes, Ballesteros became the event’s youngest champion. The following year at the Masters, he became the first European to slip on the Green Jacket. 

Ballesteros’ lasting legacy was built on Ryder Cup success. He represented Europe from 1979 to 1995, leveraging an aggressive style of play and keen intellect to post a 20-12-5 all-time record. He captained the victorious European team to a 14½ to 13½ win at Valderrama Golf Club in Spain in 1997.
profiles.quote: I really believe that when things are going your way, it is your destiny to win.

profiles.bioText:
Known for his unique sense of fashion and fluid swing, Payne Stewart captured 11 PGA TOUR wins, including three major championships, in a career cut short by tragedy. Stewart turned professional in 1979, but his breakthrough did not come until 1989 when he won the PGA Championship after starting the final round six strokes behind. 

Two years later, Stewart secured his first U.S. Open title in a playoff at Hazeltine National Golf Club in Minnesota. HIs most memorable victory came in 1999, when he dueled with Phil Mickelson and Tiger Woods over the closing holes of Pinehurst No. 2 before holing a memorable par putt on the 72nd green to secure the U.S. Open title. He died four months later in an aviation accident.
profiles.quote: In the end it's still a game of golf, and if at the end of the day you can't shake hands with your opponents and still be friends, then you've missed the point.

profiles.bioText:
Fan-favorite Fred Couples won more than 60 tournaments worldwide, including two Players Championships and the 1992 Masters, en route to becoming the first American to reach the top spot in the Official World Golf Ranking. In 1991 and 1992, Couples claimed PGA TOUR Player of the Year honors, as well as capturing the Harry Vardon Trophy for lowest scoring average. At the 1996 Players Championship, he recorded a hole-in-one in the final round on the 17th hole.

A stalwart of team competition, Couples represented the United States on five Ryder Cup and four Presidents Cup teams. During the inaugural Presidents Cup in 1994, Couples went 3-0 in his matches to lead the USA Team to victory, 20 to 12.
profiles.quote: Always count your blessings. Be thankful you are able to be out on a beautiful course. Most people in the world don’t have that opportunity.

profiles.bioText:
Ben Crenshaw, one of the game’s greatest putters, won 19 PGA TOUR titles between 1973 and 1995. Overdue to win a major after 11 years on tour, he broke through to win the 1984 Masters. An emotional triumph came 11 years later when Crenshaw earned his second Masters with the help of his long-time coach and mentor Harvey Penick, who gave Crenshaw one last putting lesson before passing away. 

After playing on three USA Ryder teams during the 1980s, Crenshaw's defining Ryder Cup moment came in 1999 when he captained the Americans to a dramatic win over Europe. The team trailed by four points heading into the Sunday singles matches, but earned 8.5 points to complete a then-record comeback.
profiles.quote: If we are going to preserve the integrity of golf as left to us by our forefathers, it is up to all of us to carry on the true spirt of the game.

profiles.bioText:
Mark O’Meara won the 1979 California State Amateur at Pebble Beach, launching a string of successes at the iconic Monterey Peninsula venue. After turning professional in 1980, he would go on to win 16 times on the PGA TOUR, including two major championships and five victories in the Bing Crosby/AT&T Pebble Beach Pro-Am.

O’Meara’s greatest triumphs came in 1998, when he claimed the Masters at Augusta National and the Open Championship at Royal Birkdale, securing PGA TOUR Player of the Year honors. He competed on Presidents Cup teams in 1996 and 1998 and on five U.S. Ryder Cup teams, playing a role on winning teams in "The War on the Shore" (1991) and "Battle of Brookline" (1999).
profiles.quote: I always get a kick out of the guys who say they’re getting their game ready to peak at the major. I’m not that good. Hey, I went into the Masters with low expectations. Look what happened there.

profiles.bioText:
Tom Kite, a student of Harvey Penick at the University of Texas, won 19 times during his career on the PGA TOUR. He remained in the top 25 of the PGA TOUR’s money list for 16 years from 1974 to 1990, leading the list outright in 1981 and 1989. 

Kite was the first golfer to reach $9 million in career earnings, but the absence of a major championship title loomed over his career until he secured a two-stroke victory in the 1992 U.S. Open at Pebble Beach. Considered by many the greatest short-iron player in golf history, Kite holed remarkable shot from the rough for birdie on the 7th hole during the final round.
profiles.quote: It's a heck of a lot harder to stay on top than it is to get there.

profiles.bioText:
Welshman Ian Woosnam was a dominant international player in the 1980s and 1990s, winning a total of 30 tournaments on the European Tour and PGA TOUR. In 1987 and 1990, he claimed European Tour Player of the Year honors and led the Order of Merit as the leading money winner on the European Tour. In 1991, Woosnam holed an 8-foot putt on the 72nd green to secure a one stroke victory at Augusta National, becoming the first player from Wales to win the Masters. 

Woosnam represented Europe on Ryder Cup teams from 1983 to 1997 with a 14-12-5 record, In 2006, he captained Europe to a decisive 18½ to 9½ victory over the United States at the K Club.
profiles.quote: I used to tell myself it had to happen if I believed in myself and worked hard enough.

profiles.bioText:
Ken Schofield oversaw a period of unprecedented growth as the First Secretary and Executive Director of the European Tour in 1975. When he became head of the Tour in 1975, there were 17 events played in the UK, Ireland and Western Europe with about $770,000 in prize money. When he stepped down 30 years later, there were 45 competitions played on four different continents with nearly $130 million in prize money.

In 1979, Schofield led the change in the Ryder Cup format to include players from continental Europe instead of only Great Britain and Ireland. He later established the Challenge Tour (the equivalent to the PGA TOUR's developmental Korn Ferry Tour), as well as the European Senior Tour.
profiles.quote: Golf was the largest part of my working life. It has enabled me to travel all over the world. It has enabled me to meet wonderful people, inside and outside the ropes. It’s been my life.

profiles.bioText:
Colin Montgomerie, a dominant force in European golf throughout the 1990s, collected 40 professional victories worldwide, including 31 on the European Tour. He finished first on the money list to secure seven consecutive European Tour Order of Merit awards from 1993 to 1999. Returning to the top of the money list in 2005, Montgomerie became the first player to earn 20 million euros on the European Tour. 

Montgomerie was named to the European Ryder Cup team nine teams between 1991 and 2006. With an individual record of 20-9-7, he earned 23.5 points and helped Europe secure six victories. Montgomerie served as captain of the 2010 European squad, which regained the Ryder Cup in a 14½-13½ win at Celtic Manor in Wales.

directus_files_id.description: Nick Price, 1993
directus_files_id.title: Player Capstone Bio1 the Global Game Nick Price

profiles.bioText:
One of the best ball-strikers in golf history, Nick Price captured three major championships, 18 PGA TOUR titles and more than 30 international events in a career that spanned four decades. In the mid-1990s, Price was regarded as the best player in the world, spending 43 weeks at the top of the World Golf Rankings and capturing back-to-back majors. The summer of 1994 became a defining moment in Price’s career when he become the first golfer since Walter Hagen in 1924 to capture the Open Championship and PGA Championship in the same year. 

Widely respected as one of the true gentlemen of the game, Price received the USGA’s Bob Jones Award in 2005 in recognition of exemplary sportsmanship.
profiles.quote: If you have a good short game you have a powerful ally.

profiles.bioText:
Charismatic and dashing, Greg Norman won more than 90 tournaments worldwide, including the Open Championship in 1986 and 1993. In 1986, his best season, he won 11 times and broke through to win the Open Championship, shooting a second round 63 at Turnberry that established a new record (since broken) for lowest round in an Open Championship. He held the top spot on the World Golf Rankings for 331 weeks in the 1980s and 1990s. 

After retiring from competitive golf, Norman established the Greg Norman Company, becoming a successful entrepreneur in golf course design, real estate, wine and golf apparel. More than a dozen companies around the world bear his name and the iconic Great White Shark logo.
profiles.quote: I’m a very intense person. When I go after something, I want to go after it with everything I have. I want to push myself to the edge.

profiles.bioText:
Masashi “Jumbo” Ozaki won more than 100 tournaments worldwide, including a record 94 victories on the Japan Golf Tour. Nicknamed for his height and length off the tee, Ozaki turned professional at 23 after a short career pitching and playing in the outfield for the Nishietsu Lions, a professional baseball team in Japan, from 1965 to 1967. 

Ozaki won his first tournament, the 1971 Japan PGA Championship, to kickstart his remarkable career. He was the leading money winner on the Japan Golf Tour twelve times from 1973 to 1993. He claimed his 100th professional victory at the 1996 Dunlop Phoenix. In 2002, Ozaki captured the final title of his career at the ANA Open, which he won for the seventh time.
profiles.quote: There's a Jumbo, and there's a Masashi. From the beginning I wanted to look good, to wear good clothes, to be in the spotlight.

profiles.bioText:
Dan Jenkins, one America’s most well-respected sports journalists and authors, was known for his wit and irreverent humor. He was a strong golfer, playing on the golf team at Texas Christian University where he studied English and journalism. After trading in his clubs for a typewriter, Jenkins launched his career as a sportswriter for the Fort Worth Press in the mid-1950s.

In 1963, Jenkins moved to Sports Illustrated, where he contributed more than 500 stories before joining Golf Digest in 1985. He would go on to cover more than 220 major championships and write more than 20 books, including the celebrated novels Semi-Tough and Dead Solid Perfect. In 1995, he received the PGA Lifetime Achievement in Journalism Award.
profiles.quote: Always keep in mind that if God didn't want a man to have mulligans, golf balls wouldn't come three to a sleeve.

profiles.bioText:
President George H.W. Bush, the 41st President of the United States, continued his family’s rich legacy of golf leadership, as well the 100-year tradition of White House golfers. George Herbert Walker, his grandfather, served as president of the USGA in 1920, notably donating the Walker Cup for competition between the USA and Great Britain. Prescott Bush, his father who taught him to play golf, served as president of the USGA in 1935.

President Bush was a low-handicap golfer, known for his fast pace on the golf course, often completing eighteen holes in less than two hours. He was a strong advocate for The First Tee, the game’s most successful youth access program, and served as the first honorary chairman in 1997.
profiles.quote: It's amazing how many people beat you at golf now that you're no longer president.

profiles.bioText:
One of Canada's finest amateur golfers, Marlene Stewart Streit won more than 20 significant amateur titles worldwide from 1951 to 2003. At the 1956 U.S. Women's Amateur, she recovered from a four-hole deficit, sinking a 12-foot putt on the 35th hole to claim a 2-and-1 victory over JoAnne Gunderson (Carner). With her victory in the 1963 Australian Ladies Amateur, Streit became the only golfer, male or female, to have won the national amateur championships of Australia, Canada, Great Britain and the United States. 

Streit won the final championship of her career in 2003 at the U.S. Senior Women's Amateur at the age of 69. In 2004, she became the first Canadian inducted into the World Golf Hall of Fame.
profiles.quote: I’m lucky that golf has always been a game to me. Win or lose, it’s a game. The gold you get is the friends.

profiles.bioText:
Carol Semple Thompson played a leading role in amateur golf from the 1960s to the 2020s, capturing 62 significant amateur titles. She competed in more than 100 USGA championships, winning the 1973 U.S. Women’s Amateur, two U.S. Women’s Mid-Amateurs and four consecutive U.S. Senior Women’s Amateur titles.

Thompson also played on a record 12 USA Curtis Cup teams from 1974 to 2002, earning a total of 20 points for the U.S. team – the closest golfer to her is Anne Quast Sander with 12 points – and captained the team in 2006 and 2008. At the 2002 Curtis Cup, Thompson made a 27-foot birdie putt on the final hole to secure the match for the United States team.
profiles.quote: It's an individual game, but no one accomplishes without backup.

profiles.bioText:
Patty Sheehan emerged as a fierce competitor at the 1980 Curtis Cup, posting a 4-0 record. Soon thereafter, she became a force on the LPGA Tour, capturing 35 career titles, including six majors. Consistency was a hallmark of Sheehan’s career, as she won at least one tournament each year from 1981 until 1996 (except for 1987). In 1984, She captured both the LPGA's Vare Trophy for lowest scoring average and the Golf Writers Association of America Female Player of the Year Award.

Sheehan represented the United States in the Solheim Cup from 1990 to 1996 and captained the USA Solheim Cup Teams in 2002 and 2003, leading her squad to a 15½ to 12½ win over Europe in 2002.
profiles.quote: I never thought of myself as anything less than a winner. To be successful, you need drive, determination and a belief in yourself, and some kind of peacefulness about what you’re doing.

profiles.bioText:
While attending The Ohio State University, Meg Mallon won the 1983 Michigan Amateur and led the Buckeyes to Big Ten titles in 1983, 1984 and 1985. She turned professional in 1987 and her breakthrough year came in 1991, when she captured four tournaments and was named Player of the Year by the Golf Writers Association of America. She would win 18 times on the LPGA Tour during her 23-year career, including four majors.

Mallon's favorite event, however, was the Solheim Cup. She represented the United States on eight consecutive teams from 1992 to 2005, posting a singles record of 5-2-1. She would go on to captain the USA squad in 2013 at Colorado Golf Club.
profiles.quote: It's nice to be well-liked, but it's even better to be well-liked and respected.

profiles.bioText:
Betsy King, who in 1998 became the first female golfer to reach $6 million in career earnings, captured 34 LPGA tournaments, including six major championships. Between 1984 and 1989, King won 20 tournaments, the most of any player in the world. She led the LPGA in earnings in 1984, 1989 and 1993 and captured the Vare Trophy for lowest scoring average in 1987 and 1993.

King played on five USA Solheim Cup teams and captained the 2007 U.S team to a 16-to-12 victory over Europe. Through all her success, King considers her Christian faith to be the center of her life. In 2007, she founded the Golf Fore Africa charity to assist women and children in need throughout Africa.
profiles.quote: My faith gives me perspective

profiles.bioText:
Juli Inkster’s stellar amateur career, highlighted by three consecutive U.S. Women’s Amateur titles, foretold future professional success. She joined the LPGA in 1983 and in 1984 captured major championship titles at the Nabisco Dinah Shore and du Maurier Classic. She went on to secure official 31 LPGA victories, including seven major championships. In 1999, her best year on tour, Inkster won five times and became the fourth woman to complete the LPGA’s career Grand Slam.

Inkster represented the United States on nine Solheim Cup teams, posting a record of 34-14-12. She served as captain in 2015, 2017 and 2019. Her 2015 team completed a historic comeback, starting the singles matches down by four points, but storming back to secure a 14½ to 13½ win.
profiles.quote: My three keys to success: One, work hard. Two, be your own person. And three, have a passion for what you're doing.

directus_files_id.description: Pat Bradley celebrates after sinking her final putt to win the 1981 U.S. Women’s Open at La Grange Country Club in Illinois
directus_files_id.title: Player Capstone Bio1 the Global Game Pat Bradley

profiles.bioText:
Every time Pat Bradley notched a victory on the LPGA Tour, her mother would ring a bell on the family porch. The bell rang 31 times, including six major championships. In 1986, Bradley became the first woman to claim three modern major titles in the same year. In so doing, she became just the third player, following Louise Suggs and Mickey Wright, to complete the LPGA’s career Grand Slam.

Bradley’s career was interrupted at its peak by a severe case of Graves' Disease (hyperthyroidism) in 1987 that left her unable to swing a club and barely able to walk. Remarkably, she returned to form, going on to become the first female player to reach $3 million and $4 million in career earnings.
profiles.quote: Commitment was the key. You can have success, failure, setback and defeat, and rise above it.

directus_files_id.title: Player Capstone Bio1 the Global Game Beth Daniel

profiles.bioText:
Beth Daniel burst onto the national golf landscape winning her first of two U.S. Women’s Amateur Championships in 1975. She won again in 1977 and the same year finished as low amateur at the U.S. Women’s Open. 

After securing Rookie of the Year honors in 1979, Daniel would go on to claim 33 LPGA titles. In 1990, her best season, she won seven times, including the LPGA Championship, and claimed her second of three Rolex Player of the Year awards. She was the LPGA’s leading money earner in 1980, 1981 and 1990 and the winner of the Vare Trophy for lowest scoring average in 1989, 1990 and 1994. Daniel represented the USA on eight Solheim Cup teams.
profiles.quote: I always said you have to be really smart or really dumb to play this game well. I just don't know where I fit in.

directus_files_id.title: Player Capstone Bio1 the Global Game Laura Davies

profiles.bioText:
Laura Davies turned professional in 1985 and won her first title on the Ladies European Tour at the Belgian Ladies Open to secure Rookie of the Year honors and the Order of Merit title. Two years later, she claimed her first major at the 1987 U.S. Women’s Open in an 18-hole playoff against fellow Hall of Fame members Ayako Okamoto and JoAnne Carner. She would go on to win more than 80 times worldwide, including four major championships.

Davies participated on 12 European Solheim Cup teams from 1990 to 2011, scoring a record 25 points over 46 matches with an overall mark of 22-18-6. In 2014, Davies was appointed Dame Commander of the Order of the British Empire, England’s highest civilian honor.
profiles.quote: Remember that it is the panic rather than the one miscreant shot which will make the difference between a good round and a bad one.

profiles.bioText:
Ayako Okamoto started her athletic career as a pitcher for Japan’s national softball team. She transitioned to golf at age 22 and joined the Japan LPGA in 1973. After winning 20 times in Japan, Okamoto joined the LPGA in 1982, claiming her first victory at the Arizona Copper Classic. She would go on to capture 62 tournaments worldwide.

Okamoto’s best year came in 1987, when she captured four titles, finished at the top of the money list, and became the first non-American to win the Rolex Player of the Year Award. A true inspiration to several generations of Japanese golfers, Okamoto leveraged her superstar status to grow the game in Japan and coach and support future stars of Japanese golf.
profiles.quote: The most important thing I have learned from my years on the LPGA Tour is this spirit of giving. Acceptance and understanding are given to those who feel lost. Material and moral support are given to those in need.

directus_files_id.title: Player Capstone Bio2 the Global Game Curtis Strange

profiles.bioText:
Curtis Strange, one of golf's most dominant players during the 1980s, won 17 times on the PGA TOUR. He played on the Wake Forest golf team—regarded as one of the best collegiate teams ever—and was a three-time All American, winning the NCAA individual title in 1974. 

In 1988, Strange won four times to earn Player of the Year honors and became the first player to earn more than $1 million dollars in a single season. His most significant career achievements came in 1988 and 1989, when he became the first player since Ben Hogan to successfully defend the U.S. Open title. Following his playing career, Strange became a golf analyst for ABC, ESPN and FOX Sports.
profiles.quote: I don't believe I have a good enough friend to give a three-footer.

profiles.bioText:
Davis Love III followed his childhood dream of playing professional golf and went on to collect 21 PGA TOUR victories, including the 1992 and 2003 Players Championship and the 1997 PGA Championship. Known for his great length of the tee, Love notched his first professional victory at the 1987 MCI Heritage Golf Classic, a tournament he would win again in 1991, 1992, 1998 and 2003. 

During the final round of the 1997 PGA Championship, Love played through steady rain until he reached the final green at Winged Foot, where the rain stopped and a rainbow appeared through the clouds. Love considered the rainbow a gift from his late father, Davis Love, Jr., a prominent teaching professional who inspired his love for the game.
profiles.quote: I used to get out there and have a thousand swing thoughts. Now I try not to have any.

directus_files_id.description: Tiger Woods launches at drive at TPC Sawgrass en route to his first of three consecutive victories in the U.S. Amateur Championship,1994
directus_files_id.title: Player Capstone Bio1 the Global Game Tiger Woods

profiles.bioText:
Tiger Woods won 82 PGA TOUR events and 15 major championships, completed the career Grand Slam three times and remains the only player to hold all four major championship titles simultaneously. Woods ranked Number 1 in the Official World Golf Rankings for a record 683 weeks, from June 2005 to October 2010. 

Woods represented the USA on eight Ryder Cup and nine Presidents Cup Teams.  He claimed the Vardon Trophy for lowest scoring average nine times and led the PGA TOUR in earnings ten times between 1997 and 2013. 

Woods’ immense popularity brought legions of new fans to the game. The TGR Foundation, established in 1996, has reached more than 2 million students with its mission to “empower students to pursue their passions through education.”
profiles.quote: I was never the most talented. I was never the biggest. I was never the fastest. I certainly was never the strongest. The only thing I had was my work ethic, and that's been what has gotten me this far.

directus_files_id.title: Player Capstone Bio2 the Global Game Tim Finchem

profiles.bioText:
A lawyer by training, Tim Finchem served in the Carter Administration as Deputy Advisor to the President in the Office of Economic Affairs. In 1994, he succeeded Deane Beman as PGA TOUR Commissioner and continued to expand the global impact of the PGA TOUR and the game. In 1997, Finchem helped establish the First Tee, which has reached more than 15 million junior golfers since its inception. 

Finchem’s legacy also includes new events such as the FedEx Cup, FedEx Cup Playoffs, World Golf Championships and the Presidents Cup. He capped off his career by spearheading
golf’s return to the Olympic Games at Rio de Janeiro in 2016.
profiles.quote: I've never played golf with Tiger Woods. To tell the truth, I'm not sure that watching him pound it 100 yards past me all day is something I'd like to do.
